Comment: This is a good example of how a chess game can suddenly change course mid-game. In this game I make two critical mistakes, the second of which quickly lost me the match
Reverse Silican
my usual development....
and black brings out its queen?!?! a basic rule of chess is to never bring out the queen too early.
preparing to bring my bishop to the long diagonal (I know there's a proper name for this but I forgot how to spell it)
Black's plan is clear now; Scholar's Mate. Not a potent attack if the opponent can recognise the danger...
as it is easily countered
? that's not usually a good place for a knight... If Black wanted to develop it then Ne7 would be far more preferable
attacking, putting my knight onto a good square and threatening a fork! (though maybe I should have moved my bishop first?)

this,Qd8 and Qc6 both work to stop the fork, but I prefer this because it keeps the queen active, whereas Qd8 wastes a lot of tempo for Black (and Qc6? threatens a discovered attack after Bf2, with the added danger of the knight playing Nf6 after that)
? bad move considering the position of Fou Leblanc... 6...c6 would be far better
? bad move considering the position of Fou Leblanc... 6...c6 would be far better
setting the attack up (I love the position of my knights here, btw :) )
Black also had the option of 7...Bb7 8. Nh4 Bxg2 9.Nxg2
discovered attack....
but Black easily sidesteps
protecting my king...
while Black goes for the attack, though I think it should have gone for more development
protection for the knight...
but Black just launches a fresh attack!
Nh3?? d6! (my knights are in a nice adjacent line again - something about this position looks really cool to me!)
